metadata.title: Boiling heat transfer performance enhancement using micro and nano structured surfaces for high heat flux electronics cooling systems

sections.text:
Flow boiling enhancement using structured surfaces in microchannels is a promising method to achieve high heat removal rates. In this study, it is aimed to study the effect of surface structure size (size scale i.e. micro and nano size) on boiling heat transfer characteristics of samples with different surface morphology. High speed and thermal cameras were employed for analyzing the obtained results. A channel with dimensions of 14×15×0.5 mm3 was utilized in the experiments. Distilled water was used as the working fluid, and the experiments were conducted at mass fluxes of 50, 75, 100 and 125 kg/m2.s. Heat transfer coefficients were obtained along with associated boiling images. Based on the visualization study results, two flow maps were constructed for a rectangular microchannel with micro and nano scale structures on copper
surfaces. It was observed that the surface morphology remarkably changed boiling heat transfer mechanisms. According to the obtained thermal images, bubble departure frequency increased with surface structures, and the surface temperature distribution was more uniform for surfaces with nano scale structures (nano-structured and micro-nano-structured) compared to other surfaces (untreated, micro-structured). The promising results reveal the potential of micro and nano scale structured surfaces for achieving improved energy efficiency for electronics cooling systems.
Keywords: Flow boiling, micro and nano structured surfaces, flow patterns, heat transfer enhancement
Nomenclature

Nu Nusselt number (-) q ′′ Heat flux (Wm-2)
P Electrical power (W), Pressure (Pa) Q Heat (W) R Thermal resistance (m2KW-1) Re Reynolds number (-) T Temperature (K) x Location from inlet (m), Variable (units vary) y Variable (units vary) Greek P∆ Pressure drop (Pa)

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Boiling is a sine qua non phenomena in our daily activities including cooking and industrial applications such as refrigeration systems, cooling of electronic devices, and chemical and petrochemical engineering [1, 2]. It has been extensively studied both numerically and experimentally for almost a semi-century by considering different parameters such as configuration, dimension, type of working fluid, heat flux, and topography of surface to improve boiling heat transfer performance [3, 4]. Flow boiling heat transfer is commonly used for having a high energy efficiency [5]. In flow boiling, nucleation, bubble growth, and bubble departure are strongly dependent on geometry, surface characteristics, size, and type of cavities on the surface [6, 7]. Many researchers focused on the use of enhanced surfaces in boiling by preparing mechanically deformed structures, porous materials, sintered wires/meshes, and complex geometries [8]. The importance of surface condition on nucleate boiling has been recognized for long time [9- 13]. It was first reported by Jakob [14] that surface roughness could considerably alter boiling characteristics on a surface. Corty and Foust [15] used a variety of roughened surfaces to show that rougher surfaces lead to lower superheats at a constant heat flux during boiling. Griffith and Willis [16] experimentally studied nucleation from a single cavity and concluded that cavity diameter and shape are important factors affecting boiling inception temperature and boiling
stability, respectively. Clark [17] conducted a visualization study using ether and pentane on vertical surfaces of pure zinc and an aluminum alloy at atmospheric pressure and concluded that cavities and protrusions on the surfaces were preferred locations for bubbles to emerge and grow. Berenson [18] concentrated on characterization of n-pentane pool boiling based on the parameters of roughness, material and cleanliness. The authors found that although the maximum nucleate-boiling heat flux and the film-boiling curve were independent of surface conditions, the surface finish raised boiling heat transfer coefficient up to 600%. The effect of micro-structured surfaces (artificial or mechanically sanded) on boiling heat transfer has been extensively investigated over the past decade [19-27]. Sauer [28] investigated boiling of refrigerant R-11 on surfaces with different roughness and concluded that at a given heat flux, heat transfer coefficient was lower for mirror finished surfaces and higher for sandpaper roughened surfaces. Precise arrays of artificial pits were applied as a surface modification technique on Cu plates by Messina and Park. [29]. The authors concluded that extremely shallow or jagged edged pits were much more effective than well-formed pits. Furthermore; the heat transfer efficiency was found to increase with pit density up to an upper limit, above which increasing pit density did not affect nucleate boiling. Benjamin and Balakrishnan [30] performed pool boiling experiments on micro-roughened surfaces using different working fluids and investigated the role of surface roughness for a given surface-liquid combination (which in turn affects the heat transfer performance). Accordingly, it was found that the thermophysical properties of the working fluid were not as significant as the surface roughness at low surface roughness values, whereas the liquid properties became important at higher roughness values. Chien et al. [31] investigated boiling heat transfer mechanisms on structured boiling surfaces with pore diameters of 0.18 and 0.23 mm. The
authors concluded that the mechanism of bubble growth on structured surfaces (mainly controlled by the liquid inertia) was different from that on the plain surface. Yu et al. [32] experimentally investigated the effect of fabricated artificial micro cavity surfaces with a cavity diameter of 200 µm and a depth of 110 µm on pool boiling heat transfer. The authors concluded that the effects of cavity density were stronger in the high heat flux region than in the low heat flux region because of the bubble/vapor coalescence near the heating surface. Advances in nanotechnology have further led to the efforts to enhance boiling heat transfer by using nanostructured surfaces such as nanowires, deposited nanoparticles, CNTs, and metal oxide structures. Takata et al. [33] used TiO2 nanoparticle sputtered surfaces (on copper) for pool boiling experiments and obtained an excellent heat transfer performance in the nucleate boiling region (up to 100%). Kanikar et al. [34] reported an enhancement of 23% in critical heat flux on copper surfaces using carbon nanotube (CNTs) coatings. The authors reported that critical heat flux was repeatable only at the low mass velocity for CNT-coated surfaces. Morshed at al. [35] deposited copper nanowires (CuNWs) on a surface of a microchannel and revealed that copper nanowires were able to enhance flow boiling heat transfer by 56%. Hendricks et al. [36] conducted pool-boiling experiments on bare and nanostructured surfaces (deposited ZnO nanoparticles on Al and Cu surfaces). The authors reported superior boiling heat transfer on nano-structured surfaces compared to a bare Al substrate. Saeidia and Alemrajabi [37] investigated the effect of nanocoatings (on aluminum surface specimens by the anodizing method) on pool boiling heat transfer and reported an enhancement of 159% in heat transfer in comparison to bare aluminum surfaces. Chu et al. [38] reported enhancements up to 200% in pool boiling critical heat flux (CHF) on hierarchically structured surfaces. The nanostructures were fabricated using electrophoretic
deposition of silica nanoparticles on microstructured silicon and electroplated copper microstructures covered with copper oxide (CuO) nanostructures. Li et al. [39] reported an early onset of nucleate boiling, a delayed onset of flow oscillation, suppressed oscillating amplitudes of temperature and pressure drop in flow boiling by synthesizing silicon nanowires in a silicon microchannel. Using the same surface enhancement (silicon nanowires), 45% pressure drop reduction, 300% critical heat flux augmentation, and boiling instability suppressing were reported by Yang et al. [40, 41] in microchannels. Zou and Maroo [42] experimentally investigated the effect of micro/nanostructure height on pool boiling heat transfer enhancement and concluded that a rise in CHF increase occurred only when the ridge heights were greater than the non-evaporating film thickness. In this study, flow boiling experiments were conducted on samples with different surface morphologies (micro and nano structures) in a high aspect ratio microchannel. There are few studies focusing on boiling heat transfer in high aspect ratio microchannels. The bubble dynamics, heat transfer mechanism, two-phase flow map, and cooling performance of different surfaces were reported with the support of thermal camera and high speed camera systems. The effect of structure size (size scale i.e. micro size and nano size), which is the main parameter in this study, on interfacial characteristics of flow boiling was revealed, and new insights into the potential of micro and nano scale structured channels for achieving high energy efficiency were introduced. Based on the obtained results, a new flow map demonstrating the differences in flow morphologies due to structure size was constructed.

sections.heading: 2. Sample preparation and characteristics
sections.text:
Three different sets of copper (Cu) samples with various surface morphologies were prepared for this study. In addition to control samples (Case A) (bare metal flat surface), micro-structured
(Case B), nano-structured (Case C), and hierarchical micro-nano-structured surfaces (Case D) (i.e. with both micro and nano-structures) were fabricated. Mechanical sanding was used to introduce micro-features to the bare Cu surface, and the resulting surfaces were considered as micro-structured surfaces. Copper oxide nanostructures were produced on the metal surface by a simple hot water treatment process [43-58], which involved immersing the copper plates in hot DI water. Sanding followed by hot water treatment process was implemented to form hierarchical (micro- and nano-) structured surfaces. Characterization of the surface morphology was performed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JEOL 7000F), and the surface wettability was examined by observing the water droplet behavior, water contact angle (CA), on
surfaces. The Sessile drop method was used to measure the CAs by dispensing a 5 μL water
drop, and the average CA from five different positions on each sample was taken into consideration. The dynamic contact angles were measured by holding the water drop with a stationary needle in contact with the surface and moving the goniometer stage along one direction. The surfaces were tilted at an angle of 25° relative to the horizontal direction. To check whether the angles are the true advancing and receding angles, the surface was further tilted to 50° (for micro-structured surface). The angles remained nearly unchanged implying that these were representatives of the advancing and receding contact angles, respectively.
The commercial copper plate (99.5% Cu) was diced into square substrates. Cu samples were polished randomly with very fine sandpaper (grit size of 3000-5000) to remove native oxides and surface contaminations. Mechanical sanding using coarse sandpaper (grit size of 1000) was performed to produce micro-structured Cu substrate. Then, samples were cleaned by ultrasonicating them in a three solution cleaning process (i.e. acetone + IP + DI water). For nanostructured Cu substrates, polished and cleaned samples were immersed in hot ultra-pure DI
water. The water temperature was kept at 80oC using a temperature controlled hot plate for 24 hours. Hierarchically structured (micro-nano-structured) Cu substrates were fabricated by sanding with the use of course sand paper (grit size of 1000) (identical conditions of microstructured Cu substrate fabrication), cleaning (i.e. acetone + IP + DI water + drying) and treatment of boiling ultra-pure DI water at 80°C for 24 hours (under the same conditions as nanostructured Cu substrate fabrication). Fig. 1 shows the surface morphology of tested samples. Also, water contact angle on Cu surfaces are reported in Table 1.
(Case A)
Micro scale structured
Cu (micro-structured)
(Case B) 78.5
Nano scale structured
Cu nano-structured
(Case C) 120.16
Cu micro-nano-structured
(Case D) 140.75
It can be seen from Fig. 1 that the sanded sample (micro-structured surface (Case B)) has the formation of micro scale grooves due to the mechanical erosion of Cu surface via sanding. These grooves are one-directional, long and have a size with diameter of less than 10 µm. On the other hand, the SEM image of nano-structured Cu surfaces (Case C) reveals that treatment with hot water generated nanoscale features (copper oxide nanostructures) similar to leaves of thickness ~15 nm and width ~250 nm, which are consistent with the earlier reports [44, 59]. Moreover, micro-nano-structured Cu samples (Case D) show that a hierarchical micro-nano-structured surface, which has both micro features from sanding and nano leaves from hot water treatment, was achieved.
Surface profiles and cavity size distributions of examined surfaces, which were obtained with the surface profilometry technique (KLA-TENCOR P7 Surface Profiler), are shown in Fig. 2 and Fig. 3, respectively. The surface profile meter is able to precisely characterize surface roughness and waviness (as small as 4 Å, especially on surfaces with maximum height up to 1 µm) (Case A and Case C) [60]. As expected, micro- and micro-nano-structured surfaces have cavity sizes in the range of 3-6 µm. Although untreated and nano-structured surfaces have not been exposed to any mechanical sanding process, the presence of nanoscale features (copper oxide
nanostructures) on nano-structured surfaces raises the surface roughness, and as can be seen in Fig. 2, they have relatively higher peaks and valleys in comparison to untreated surfaces. Furthermore, according to obtained results shown in Fig. 3, the cavity distribution is more uniform on the nano-structured and micro-nano-structured surfaces (Case C and Case D) in comparison to untreated and micro-structured surfaces (Case A and Case B).
Fig. 2. Surface profiles of untreated, micro-, nano-, and micro-nano-structured Cu samples
Fig. 3. Cavity distribution on untreated, micro-, nano-, and micro-nano-structured Cu samples

sections.heading: 3. Experimental Setup & Procedure
sections.text:
Fig. 4 shows the test section. The experiments were performed in a closed loop configuration. From an inlet reservoir, distilled water was pumped to the test section via a micro annular gear pump (HNPM_ mzr-7205), which can provide a constant mass flow rate. The pump was equipped with a digital flow meter, which was calibrated by the bucket and stopwatch method
[61]. Aluminum is chosen as the base material because of its ease for machinability and high thermal conductivity. 4 cartridge heaters, 5 thermocouples and 1 pressure gauge were integrated to the aluminum block with designated holes. Cartridge heaters, which have diameters of 7.5 mm, are connected to a DC power supply (AMETEK Sorensen) while the OMEGA thermocouples of a diameter of 3 mm are connected to digital thermometers (UNI-T UT325). An OMEGA pressure gauge was connected to the system to measure the inlet pressure. A 15×15 mm groove as the housing for plates was formed on top of the heating zone. The micro pump (HNP Mikrosysteme GmbH) pumps the working fluid (DI water), which passes through a channel with dimensions of 14×15×0.5 mm3 (length, width, and height, respectively). In order to prevent any leakage, the system was sealed with a Plexiglas cover an O-ring around the path and proper bolts. The Plexiglas can also offer the advantage of visualization. Flow patterns were visualized via a miniature microscope (SPI mbH) and a high speed camera located at the top of the samples. A FLIR SC325 Thermal Camera was used for acquiring thermal images.

sections.heading: 5. Results and discussion
sections.text: The experiments were performed on four sample types, namely Cu bare (untreated surface, Case A), Cu micro (micro-structured, Case B), Cu nano (nano-structured, Case C), and Cu micro-nano (micro-nano-structured, Case D). Furthermore; it should be noted that the micro scale structured surface refers to Cu micro (micro-structured, Case B), while the nano scale structured surfaces refer to both Cu nano (nano-structured, Case C) and Cu micro-nano (micro-nano-structured or hierarchical surfaces, Case D).

sections.heading: 5.1 Single phase studies
sections.text:
Prior to flow boiling experiments, single phase heat transfer tests were conducted to validate the experimental setup and procedure. The tests section is a rectangular channel with an aspect ratio of 30 and is heated from the bottom. Accordingly, the obtained Nusselt numbers and friction factors for the experimental range of Reynolds numbers were compared to the results obtained from a correlation in the literature (shown in Table 3), which was recommended for flows between two parallel plates (one side heated [63]). Here, x is the distance from the beginning of the heated section, Pr is the Prandtl number, and Re is the Reynolds number.
The obtained friction factor and average heat transfer coefficient results are shown in Fig. 5. The obtained friction factors are in good agreement with the predictions of the correlation. Experimental heat transfer coefficients are higher than the predicted ones. The main reason for deviation is due to heat transfer through the side walls in the experimental setup despite of the
high aspect ratio. The mean absolute error (MAE), relative mean bias error (MBE), and root mean square error (RMSE) serve for the comparison of the experimental data with the predictions of available correlations. While the MBE provides information about underestimation or overestimation of the experimental data, MAE and RMSE are indicators of how close the experimental data and predictions are [64, 65]. Negative and positive MBE values imply underestimation and overestimation of the experimental data, respectively. A detailed comparison is displayed in Table 4. Obtained experimental friction factors (-6.12% MBE and 20.59% RMSE) are overpredicted by the correlation, while Nusselt numbers (18% MBE and 18.13% RMSE) are underpredicted by the correlation with acceptable errors.
Fig. 5. Comparison between obtained experimental results and predictions of correlations a) Friction factor b) Average heat transfer coefficient
In general, obtained friction factors and Nusselt numbers data are predicted by the correlations with mean absolute errors (MAE) of 10.55% and 20.84%, respectively.
Table 4. Error analysis for obtained Nusselt numbers and friction factors
MBE% MAE% RMSE%
Nusselt number -12.53% 20.84% 21.07%
Friction factor -6.90% 10.55% 12.64%
The effect of surface structures (micro and nano scale structures) on average heat transfer coefficient for the single phase region is shown in Fig. 6 According to the obtained results, surfaces with nano scale structures (Case C and D) lead to slightly higher heat transfer coefficients in comparison to micro-structured (Case B) and bare surfaces (Case A), which is related to the larger surface area of micro-nano-structured surfaces related to the projected area [66].
Fig. 6. Heat transfer coefficient for the single phase study on copper surfaces
5.2 Flow boiling
Flow boiling images of structured copper plates are shown in Fig. 7 for two different heat fluxes of 7 and 12 (W/cm2) and the mass flux of 50 kg/m2.s. Obtained images were processed via a script implemented with National Instruments IMAQ Vision Builder 2016. The complete script consists of 12 steps as described in Puli et al. [67]. More bubbles and smaller bubble sizes are observed for plates with structures, which is due to lower surface energy of the solid surface and larger density of active nucleation sites [44]. At higher heat fluxes, more elongated bubbles are detected on the plain surface (heat flux of 12 W/cm2) (Case A), while isolated and elongated bubbles are seen for micro scale structured surfaces (Case B). Furthermore; it was observed that nano scale structured surfaces (Case C and D) provide more active nucleation sites at a fixed applied heat flux. Although the size of cavities on nano scale structured surfaces (Case C and D) is small relative to the required critical cavity size at the corresponding wall superheat, nanostructures act together to form an active nucleation site [68]. Flow boiling takes place in a high aspect ratio microchannel. As a result, bubbles are attached to the plate from bottom and to the plexiglass from top and act as an obstacle for the flow. Consequently, the flow passes along both sides of attached bubbles (shown by yellow arrows in Fig. 7).
Fig. 7. Flow boiling visualization results for copper surfaces. Two heat fluxes of 7 W/cm2 (moderate) and 12 W/cm2 (high) heat fluxes were applied for nucleate and saturated flow boiling
Fig. 8a shows a nucleation bubble over a cavity. Equating the temperature at the top of the bubble to the local liquid temperature gives the desired nucleation criteria [25, 69]. Accordingly, the range of critical cavity size is obtained as (Fig. 8a):

Accordingly, Fig. 8b shows the nucleation criterion of the three widely used correlations, and corresponding wall superheat for nucleation. As expected, although the required wall superheat for nano-structured surfaces is higher than 5oC, nucleation was observed at lower wall temperatures.
Fig. 9. Bubble size distribution for different surfaces at two heat fluxes of 7 W/cm2 (moderate) and 13 W/cm2 (high) heat fluxes.
The obtained heat transfer coefficients for copper surfaces at two different mass fluxes as a function of heat flux are shown in Fig. 10. According to the obtained results, nano scale structured surfaces (Case C and D) have higher heat transfer coefficients especially for the nucleate boiling region towards the saturated boiling regime in comparison to the base surfaces. The maximum heat transfer enhancement at mass flux of 50 kg/m2.s for micro-structured (Case B), nano-structured (Case C), and micro-nano-structured (Case D) surfaces in comparison to the base samples (Case A) are 16%, 25%, and 36%, respectively. More active nucleation sites, and
uniform distribution of active nucleation sites on surfaces with nano structures (Case C and Case D, shown in Fig. 12) are the main reason for this amount of enhancement. Also, single phase studies indicate that these surfaces have a larger surface area (Fig. 6), which further enhances convective heat transfer in the nucleate boiling region. On the other hand, nano scale structured surfaces (Case C and D) show a better heat transfer coefficient performance compared to microstructured surface (Case B) in the saturated regime. Nano scale structured surfaces (Case C and D) provide enhanced quasi-periodic liquid–solid contacts, which enables enhanced local quenching of the heater surface [72]. The configuration having both micro and nano structures (Case D) provides the maximum enhancement due to confined effect of micro and nano structures.
Fig. 10. Heat transfer coefficients at the mass fluxes of a) 50 b) 125 (kg/ m2.s)
Furthermore, flow visualization (Fig. 11) reveals that bubbles move at higher velocities on nano scale structured surfaces (case C and D) than the bare and micro-structured surfaces (case A and B, respectively). The bubble release frequency of such surfaces is also higher than the micro-
structured and plain surfaces. The average enhancement in heat transfer coefficients are 7%, 15%, and 22% for micro-structured (case B), nano-structured (case C), micro-nano-structured (case D) surfaces at the mass flux of 50 (kg/ m2.s), respectively, while they are 13%, 24%, and 30% at the mass flux of 125 (kg/m2.s), respectively.
Fig. 11. Bubble and elongated bubble motion for plain (case A), micro-structured (case B), nanostructured (case C) and micro-nano-structured plate (case D) at the heat flux of 11 (W/cm2) and the mass flux of 50 (kg/m2.s)
Flow boiling heat transfer is governed by two mechanisms namely nucleate boiling and forced
convective boiling as fcnbfb hhh += [13]. Here, nbh and fch stand for the heat transfer due to
nucleate boiling and forced convective boiling. While convective boiling heat transfer occurs across a thin liquid film, which suppresses bubble formation and subsequent growth, nucleate boiling heat transfer mechanism dominates at low heat flux and Reynolds number, and has similarities with nucleate pool boiling. Therefore; in this study, in order to assess the nucleate boiling concept, pool boiling experiments were conducted on structured plates at low wall superheats. The corresponding temperature distributions obtained by thermal camera and bubble images related to nucleate boiling are shown in Fig. 12. As expected, surface temperatures are smaller for nano scale structured surfaces, which generate smaller bubbles. Furthermore; surface temperature gradient is higher on untreated surfaces compared to micro-structured surfaces and on micro-structured surfaces (Case B) compared to nano scale structured surfaces (Case C and D).
Fig. 12. Bubble distribution and size and corresponding temperature distributions for examined surfaces (heat flux of 10 W/cm2)
Vapor phase distribution (vapor quality is 0.1 for all the cases) on plain and nano-structured surfaces at the mass flux of 125 (kg/m2.s) and the heat flux of 17 (W/cm2) is shown in Fig. 13. Bigger vapor blankets and elongated bubbles corresponding to bubbly/slug and slug/annular flow regimes exist for the plain surface at the same heat flux, whereas smaller and more dispersed bubbles and less elongated bubbles are visible on the nano-structured surface.
Fig. 14a and Fig. 14b show the variation of heat transfer coefficient with vapor quality in the middle of the samples for mass fluxes of 50 and 125 kg/m2.s, respectively. As can be seen, a decreasing trend is visible after an increasing trend. Transition from nucleate boiling domination to convective boiling domination is responsible for this change in the trend, which is shown in
Fig. 14c. First, isolated bubbly flow regime is apparent at low heat flux. With the increase in heat flux, elongated bubbly flow and slug flow patterns appear, when the heat transfer mechanism transition from nucleate boiling to convective boiling occurs.
According to the obtained results shown in Fig. 10a, heat fluxes of 11 and 12 W/cm2 correspond to subcooled flow boiling for the mass flux of 50 kg/m2.s. As seen in Fig. 14c, at the heat flux of 11 W/cm2, nano scale structured surfaces provide smaller bubbles, which move with higher velocities in comparison to the untreated copper surface. It should be noted that case C (nanostructured surfaces) and case D (micro-nano-structured surfaces) have similar results in regard to interfacial velocities.
In order to construct the flow boiling map, the results corresponding to mass fluxes of 75 and 100 kg/m2.s were also included for interfacial velocity calculations and visualization process in addition to the mass fluxes of 50 and 125 kg/m2.s. Visualization of flow patterns for various mass fluxes, vapor qualities, and heat fluxes was performed using the high speed camera. The required parameters for the development of the flow maps are directly measured in the experiments. The effect of mass flux, vapor quality and density are included in the superficial velocity calculation, which is commonly used in flow pattern maps. It should be noted that the superficial velocities refer to the relative velocity of the liquid and vapor phases, separately
( gl
l
AA
Q
+ =lJ and
gl
g
AA
Q
+ =gJ , where Q is volumetric flow rate and A is area). For example,
high and low superficial vapor velocities occur for the annular flow pattern, where the vapor core has a higher velocity than the liquid film. The boundaries among flow patterns are plotted based on the liquid and vapor superficial velocities in the flow maps.
The obtained flow maps for bare (Case A), micro-structured (Case B), nano-structured (Case C), and micro-nano-structured (Case D) surfaces are shown in Fig. 15. There are minor differences between flow patterns of untreated and micro-structured surfaces, and those of nano-structured and micro-nano-structured surfaces. Therefore, the flow maps are given in two different groups.
Four types of flow patterns are observed, namely Bubbly, Slug, Semi/wavy annular and Annular flows, which is in agreement with the literature [26]:
Bubbly flow (Isolated/confined and elongated bubbles): In the isolated bubble regime, the bubble diameter is smaller than the channel size. For untreated surfaces, this flow regime is observable for a small range of heat fluxes, while for nano-structured surfaces this flow regime is more extended. As the quality increases, coalescence of bubbles forms larger bubbles, which leads to the plug flow. In the elongated bubble regime, due to the small channel dimensions, the bubbles start growing in the axial direction. As the bubbles grow and their size approaches the channel size, a thin liquid film appears, which is surrounded by the elongated bubbles filling the gap between the bubble and the channel walls. Slug flow: As the length of the elongated bubbles increases along the channel, the face of the trailing bubble meets the rear of the leading bubble to form large vapor plugs, which is large compared to an elongated bubble. Liquid slugs or sometimes small liquid drops are present between consecutive vapor plugs. Slug/semi-annular flow: At low and medium mass fluxes, the transition from slug to annular flow occurs in this region, where the two large slugs meet to form the wavy annular pattern. In this region, the rear of elongated bubbles is more and more deformed, and both elongated vapor slugs and liquid rings exist. Annular flow: Annular flow is characterized with a continuous liquid ring surrounding the channel walls, whose thickness decreases with an increase in the vapor fraction along the tube. The thickness of the liquid film also decreases with an increase in the heat flux at a given position. The vapor flows in the channel core, while small liquid droplets are entrained in the vapor core.
Fig. 15. Experimental flow maps in two groups for a) unstructured and micro scale structured surfaces (Case A and B) b) nano scale structured (Case C and D) (nano- and micro-nanostructured)
On the nano scale structured surfaces (Case C and D), bubbly flow initiates at lower superficial gas velocities. This is mainly due to higher contact angle of nano-structured surfaces. The existence of bubbly flow at lower vapor fractions on nano-structured surfaces shifts the bubbly flow transition line to lower values of superficial gas velocity, resulting in widening the bubbly flow zone. Due to smaller bubbles emerging from nano-structured surfaces under the same conditions, the transition from bubbly flow to slug flow also delayed. The transition from slug to semi annular flow pattern has also a change with nano-structures in comparison to the untreated surfaces. Since vapor venting on nano-structured surfaces is higher, vapor density is lower as a result of lower system pressure. This causes higher vapor velocities and results in early transition from slug to semi annular and semi annular to annular flow patterns as seen in Fig. 15.
7. Conclusion:
In this study, the effect of micro and nano scale structured surfaces on flow boiling in a high aspect ratio rectangular microchannel was studied. Copper surfaces were used as the test samples. Based on obtained results it was found that structured surfaces have a better heat removal capacity in comparison to the bare surface. Therefore, it can be claimed that microstructured, nano-structured, and micro-nano-structured plates can be implemented in various cooling applications to achieve higher energy efficiency. The effect of surface structure becomes more dominant as the flow rate increases. According to the obtained results, higher heat transfer coefficients are obtained from nano scale structured surfaces in comparison to the micro scale structured sample. More active nucleation sites at the same heat flux and a lower wall superheat at the boiling inception are two major differences between structured and bare surfaces. Furthermore; vapor blankets tend to move near the side wall boundaries at much higher velocities on nano scale structured surfaces in comparison to bare samples, which remarkably enhances the cooling performance in the fully developed saturated flow boiling region. It was found that the difference in heat transfer mechanism and interfacial properties between Cases A and D (bare Cu and micro-nano-structured surfaces, respectively) is much more than that between Cases C and D (nano-structured and micro-nano-structured surfaces, respectively). A new flow map is constructed based on the obtained experimental results (in two groups of i) unstructured and micro scale structured surfaces, and ii) nano scale structured surfaces (nanostructured and micro-nano-structured)). The delays in transition from bubbly flow to slug flow and slug flow to wavy annular flow exist on nano scale structured surfaces.

referenceMentions.context: Boiling is a sine qua non phenomena in our daily activities including cooking and industrial applications such as refrigeration systems, cooling of electronic devices, and chemical and petrochemical engineering [1, 2].

Boiling is a sine qua non phenomena in our daily activities including cooking and industrial applications such as refrigeration systems, cooling of electronic devices, and chemical and petrochemical engineering [1, 2].

It has been extensively studied both numerically and experimentally for almost a semi-century by considering different parameters such as configuration, dimension, type of working fluid, heat flux, and topography of surface to improve boiling heat transfer performance [3, 4].

It has been extensively studied both numerically and experimentally for almost a semi-century by considering different parameters such as configuration, dimension, type of working fluid, heat flux, and topography of surface to improve boiling heat transfer performance [3, 4].
Flow boiling heat transfer is commonly used for having a high energy efficiency [5].
In flow boiling, nucleation, bubble growth, and bubble departure are strongly dependent on geometry, surface characteristics, size, and type of cavities on the surface [6, 7].
In flow boiling, nucleation, bubble growth, and bubble departure are strongly dependent on geometry, surface characteristics, size, and type of cavities on the surface [6, 7].
Many researchers focused on the use of enhanced surfaces in boiling by preparing mechanically deformed structures, porous materials, sintered wires/meshes, and complex geometries [8].
It was first reported by Jakob [14] that surface roughness could considerably alter boiling characteristics on a surface.
Corty and Foust [15] used a variety of roughened surfaces to show that rougher surfaces lead to lower superheats at a constant heat flux during boiling.
Griffith and Willis [16] experimentally studied nucleation from a single cavity and concluded that cavity diameter and shape are important factors affecting boiling inception temperature and boiling

Clark [17] conducted a visualization study using ether and pentane on vertical surfaces of pure zinc and an aluminum alloy at atmospheric pressure and concluded that cavities and protrusions on the surfaces were preferred locations for bubbles to emerge and grow.
Berenson [18] concentrated on characterization of n-pentane pool boiling based on the parameters of roughness, material and cleanliness.
The effect of micro-structured surfaces (artificial or mechanically sanded) on boiling heat transfer has been extensively investigated over the past decade [19-27].
The effect of micro-structured surfaces (artificial or mechanically sanded) on boiling heat transfer has been extensively investigated over the past decade [19-27].

The effect of micro-structured surfaces (artificial or mechanically sanded) on boiling heat transfer has been extensively investigated over the past decade [19-27].
The effect of micro-structured surfaces (artificial or mechanically sanded) on boiling heat transfer has been extensively investigated over the past decade [19-27].
The effect of micro-structured surfaces (artificial or mechanically sanded) on boiling heat transfer has been extensively investigated over the past decade [19-27].

Sauer [28] investigated boiling of refrigerant R-11 on surfaces with different roughness and concluded that at a given heat flux, heat transfer coefficient was lower for mirror finished surfaces and higher for sandpaper roughened surfaces.

Benjamin and Balakrishnan [30] performed pool boiling experiments on micro-roughened surfaces using different working fluids and investigated the role of surface roughness for a given surface-liquid combination (which in turn affects the heat transfer performance).
[31] investigated boiling heat transfer mechanisms on structured boiling surfaces with pore diameters of 0.
[32] experimentally investigated the effect of fabricated artificial micro cavity surfaces with a cavity diameter of 200 μm and a depth of 110 μm on pool boiling heat transfer.
[33] used TiO2 nanoparticle sputtered surfaces (on copper) for pool boiling experiments and obtained an excellent heat transfer performance in the nucleate boiling region (up to 100%).
[34] reported an enhancement of 23% in critical heat flux on copper surfaces using carbon nanotube (CNTs) coatings.
[35] deposited copper nanowires (CuNWs) on a surface of a microchannel and revealed that copper nanowires were able to enhance flow boiling heat transfer by 56%.
[36] conducted pool-boiling experiments on bare and nanostructured surfaces (deposited ZnO nanoparticles on Al and Cu surfaces).

Saeidia and Alemrajabi [37] investigated the effect of nanocoatings (on aluminum surface specimens by the anodizing method) on pool boiling heat transfer and reported an enhancement of 159% in heat transfer in comparison to bare aluminum surfaces.
[38] reported enhancements up to 200% in pool boiling critical heat flux (CHF) on hierarchically structured surfaces.

[39] reported an early onset of nucleate boiling, a delayed onset of flow oscillation, suppressed oscillating amplitudes of temperature and pressure drop in flow boiling by synthesizing silicon nanowires in a silicon microchannel.

Zou and Maroo [42] experimentally investigated the effect of micro/nanostructure height on pool boiling heat transfer enhancement and concluded that a rise in CHF increase occurred only when the ridge heights were greater than the non-evaporating film thickness.

metadata.abstractText: Flow boiling enhancement using structured surfaces in microchannels is a promising method to achieve high heat removal rates. In this study, it is aimed to study the effect of surface structure size (size scale i.e. micro and nano size) on boiling heat transfer characteristics of samples with different surface morphology. High speed and thermal cameras were employed for analyzing the obtained results. A channel with dimensions of 14×15×0.5 mm was utilized in the experiments. Distilled water was used as the working fluid, and the experiments were conducted at mass fluxes of 50, 75, 100 and 125 kg/m.s. Heat transfer coefficients were obtained along with associated boiling images. Based on the visualization study results, two flow maps were constructed for a rectangular microchannel with micro and nano scale structures on copper
metadata.creator: Elsevier
